bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Department of Agriculture, August 13, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks permission from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to bring pieces of wood from the framboyant tree on the supposed site of Camp Lazear into the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Department of Agriculture, August 13, 1940
div1.opener:
August 13, 1940
Department of Agriculture
Washington, D. C.
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
At the request of the President of Washington and Jefferson College,
Washington, Pa., I have been doing some historical researches on the conquest
of yellow fever, and the work of Walter Reed and the other members of the Army
Commission in 1900. Washington and Jefferson College is going to have quite
a celebration in October, honoring Lazear, who, you may remember, died a martyr
to medical science.

In connection with the dedication of their Lazear Memorial Building,
I have recently made a trip to Havana to interview survivors of the experiments,
etc. There is a “memorial tree” in Cuba on the site of which the Cuban government
is going to erect, at considerable cost, a fitting memorial. I was able to
obtain a limb of this tree which is on the supposed site of Camp Lazear. This
has been out up in small pieces, my purpose being to have certain small objects,
such as gavels, pen holders, etc. made from the limb.

I was informed by the customs man at Havana that I could not bring
this wood in without special permission from your department. It is a framboyant
tree, which I believe is the same as our poinsetta tree. I am most anxious
to have your authorized permission to have this admitted to the country in the
raw form. There will be several sections of the limb, each section about one
to three feet in length. If there are no quarantine regulations against this
wood and if you can give me authority to have this shipped in, I will appreciate
it greatly if you will send me a duplicate copy of the letter and I will mail
it to my agent in Havana. It can then be attached to the outside of the package
so that when it arrives in customs in New York there will be no question about
its admission
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
